newsitem.title: USA: EPA announces 16 new "brownfields" cleanup sites.
newsitem.headline: EPA announces 16 new "brownfields" cleanup sites.

text.p: EPA Administrator Carol Browner said she will formally announce the next series of federal grants to help U.S. cities clean up and redevelop "brownfield" sites on Tuesday.
Brownfields are abandoned, often polluted sites that are not contaminated enough to qualify for cleanup under the Superfund program administered by the Environmental Protection Agency.
Browner, who launched the administration's brownfields program with a $200,000 grant to Cleveland in November 1993, said tomorrow she will award grants of up to $200,000 each to 16 cities.

The cities are Oakland, Calif.; Naugatuck Valley and New Haven, Conn.; Silver Valley, Idaho; Portland, Maine; Somerville, Mass.; suburbs of Dearborn, Mich.; Kalamazoo, Mich.; Bonne Terre, Mo.; Concord, N.H.; Cincinnati, Ohio; Sious Falls, S.D.; Salt Lake City and Murray, Utah; Port of Bellingham, Wash.; and Puyallup Tribe in Tacoma, Wash.
In his 1996 State of the Union Address, President Clinton announced $2 billion worth of tax incentives for businesses that buy and clean up brownfields sites, EPA said.
EPA added, "In August 1996, the President announced an expansion of EPA grants which will result in the clean up of approximately 5,000 sites by (the year) 2000."
